Sure, here is a continuation of Little Deer's story where he and his friends look in the river:

---

After a long day of playing and exploring with my friends, we all went down to the Potomac River to cool off and relax. The sun was beginning to set, casting a warm orange glow over the water.

We waded into the river and splashed around, laughing and shouting. As we played, some of the other children noticed their reflections in the water. They called out to the rest of us, and soon we were all gathered around, staring down at our own images.

I looked at my reflection, curious and a little bit shy. I saw my dark hair, my brown eyes, and the beaded necklace that my mother had given me. I saw my friends next to me, their own reflections looking back up at them.

We started making silly faces at each other, giggling at the distorted images that stared back. Some of the girls pretended to smooth down their hair, while some of the boys flexed their muscles. We all felt a sense of playfulness and joy, our worries and responsibilities forgotten for a moment.

As we gazed into the water, we also noticed the reflections of the trees and the sky above. The water was like a mirror, showing us a different perspective on the world around us. We pointed out different shapes and colors, marveling at the beauty of nature.

Eventually, the sun began to dip below the horizon, and we knew it was time to head back to our village. But the memory of our reflections in the river stayed with us, a reminder of the joy and wonder of childhood.
